head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #29

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #29 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks on Board the Nancy in the month of October 1813 – in the Port of Makinac[.]

Fore part of this day blows fresh from the SSW, the weather becomes more mild – cloudy & looks like rain – discharged the last of the ordinance & some more merchandise, latter of this 24 hours still continuing to blow from the Southward with no abatement[.] Several Canoes go for Montreal this day[.]

Fore & latter part of this day wind at South & blowing moderately about ½ past 10 AM Mr Robert Dicks[on] arrived from Kingston – cloudy cool weather & threatening rain – waited on the commanding officer for orders – no duty done on board – at 8 PM set the watch – very dark & cloudy[.]

Fore part of this day turned out the last of the cargo – little wind from ENE cloudy weather & cool sent the boat for fire wood – latter part of the day wind continues from the eastward threatening rain, the boat returns with a load of wood – at 8 PM set the Watch (about 3 PM recd orders from Capt Bullock to sail for St Maries & lay the Vessel up – for the winter)
I recd these orders in presence of Lewis Crawford Esqr & Capt Mackay at Doctor Mitchells

Fore part of this day wind at N:E – cloudy & looks like rain, Mr R: Dickson goes for the Indian country – Messrs McKay & Crawford for Montreal latter part calm & spitting rain, an express arrives from Montreal – at 8 PM Set the watch[.]

Fore part of this day cloudy cool weather, wind at NW, recd some provisions on board – latter part, wind abates, continues cloudy, & cool – several Indian canoes arrived from L'arbe croshe, with corn, at 8 PM Set the watch[.]

Fore part of this day cloudy & foggy, wind at East & moderate, latter part wind at ENE & freshens with light rain dull heavy weather recd some liquor on board this day for the use of the men during the winter – at ½ past 6 PM commences raining violently – at 8 PM set the watch, rain continues all night.

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
